text:
Morning, all. I wanted to get some opinions from you all. I’ve been hesitant to implement the new drag and drop functionality that HubSpot has released. However some of our clients have been requesting it as of late and I’m torn.

Pre the new drag and drop our team came up with a rock solid “modular” approach of which many of you probably do something very similar. It’s essentially one big flexible column that you can drag custom modules into to create your own unique layouts without going off-brand. It allows us to go “gridless” and create some really impressive modern layouts. Our design team loves it and I can’t say I miss a grid either. Our clients have been happy with this style of site management.

My hesitations with the drag and drop builds really boil down to a few things:

• The need for a 12 column grid system. I try not to use a grid system these days and go “gridless” with CSS Grid or Flexbox. What if you want 5 columns in a 12 column grid? What if you want a “broken grid layout” Go custom module?
• If you start making custom modules you start to have a mix of modules. Some full width and don’t work within columns, some that work within columns. Some that are drag and drop, some that are not. And that site management UX seems like it would be confusing to the client. Which module should I be using? I can adjust columns in this area, but not this one?
• Drag and drop almost seems like too much control. Clients can (and most likely will) jack the site up with too much control. I do see pros to this as well, but it goes both ways. Our current modular method may be a bit more restrictive, but it prevents inconsistencies.
• Etc.
Maybe our team needs a mixture of both “modular” and “drag and drop”.

TL;DR. I see some really impressive control with drag and drop, but at the same time its a bit limiting. What are your opinions. Are you all in on it? Don’t use it? Use a mixture?

I pretty much solely use dnd areas. They make life way faster. Content teams seem to like it a lot better because they don’t need to rely on devs all the time. And it gives you the benefit of being able to build grid less if you want or with the standard grid. 

Each dnd section allows you to go full width. So if you use any of your gridless modules you can still make them do what they are supposed to do. 

If you haven’t at the very least adopted themes yet I would say that you are pretty far behind the train in terms of making life heckin great for future you, your dev team, and your content team.

I def have a mix of custom modules that are grid based and not grid based. Never have had any real issues with clients on it. 

They tend to stick to what is already on the site and often times will reference things that are already built. They might just click on it to see what the module is called and then pull it into the page that they are making.

At the end of the day I think if your modules are named clearly — you shouldn’t have any real issues with it. And if you’re still worried about it you can build a modules page to showcase how modules are intended to be used.

Thanks for the feedback, BJ. I definitely use Themes. That’s be fantastic. But I don’t however use the drag and drop functionality.

What type of naming convention do you use for modules to help identify if something is full width or maybe a small element like a button that it to be used within the grid?

We usually just add a FW prefix if it’s supposed to be Full Width. But typically if a client pulls something onto the page and it doesnt look quite right. It’s easy to figure out that you need to make it full width.

Also worth noting that you can now create premade sections. So you can create a whole area that a user can just drop into their page. Which means you can preset the section to full width if the module calls for that. Then there really isnt any configuring outside of the module that needs to be done

Interesting side note. <https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Container_Queries|CSS container queries> are going to make it more easy to think of modules as adaptable to being used at multiple sizes.
